document_title: Knee and Hip Joint Cartilage Damage from Combined Spaceflight Hazards of Low-Dose Radiation Less than 1 Gy and Prolonged Hindlimb Unloading
summary_full: This study investigated the individual and combined effects of reduced weight bearing (hindlimb unloading, HLU) and low-dose radiation (≤1 Gy) on knee and hip joint cartilage in mice. Eighty C57BL/6J mice were subjected to HLU or remained weight-bearing, and then exposed to 0, 0.1, 0.5, or 1.0 Gy of X-rays. After 30 days, cartilage volume and thickness were reduced, particularly at weight-bearing contact points, in all treatment groups compared to controls. Collagen content was also decreased. Circulating serum cartilage oligomeric matrix protein (sCOMP), a marker of cartilage degradation, increased in all irradiated groups. Proteomic analysis revealed a decrease in cartilage compositional proteins indicative of osteoarthritis. The findings demonstrate that both HLU and spaceflight-relevant radiation doses, individually and combined, lead to cartilage degradation and an arthritic phenotype, with low-dose irradiation causing an active catabolic response.
key_findings: Hindlimb unloading (HLU) and low-dose radiation (≤1 Gy) individually and combined cause cartilage degradation in knee and hip joints.
Cartilage volume and thickness were reduced in all treatment groups compared to ground-sham controls, especially at weight-bearing contact points.
Collagen content in articular cartilage was decreased across all treatment groups.
Circulating serum cartilage oligomeric matrix protein (sCOMP) increased in all irradiated groups, indicating active cartilage catabolism.
Proteomic analysis identified a decrease in cartilage compositional proteins, suggesting an early arthritic phenotype.
Low-dose irradiation (0.1-1.0 Gy) induced an active catabolic response in cartilage 24 days post-irradiation.
future_research_fields: Prevention strategies for cartilage degradation during long-term spaceflight.
Investigating the effects of prolonged exposure to reduced weight bearing and spaceflight-relevant radiation doses.
Studying the long-term consequences of combined HLU and low-dose radiation on joint health.
Evaluating the efficacy of countermeasures against radiation-induced cartilage damage.
Research into the specific mechanisms of cartilage degradation induced by low-LET X-rays and high-LET space radiation.

conclusions: Both hindlimb unloading and spaceflight-relevant low-dose radiation, individually and in combination, lead to cartilage degradation and an arthritic phenotype in mouse knee and hip joints. These challenges, particularly low-dose radiation, induce an early catabolic response in cartilage, highlighting a significant risk to astronaut joint health during long-duration space missions.
impact_statement: This study reveals that combined spaceflight hazards of reduced weight bearing and low-dose radiation significantly damage joint cartilage, potentially accelerating osteoarthritis in astronauts and necessitating the development of protective countermeasures.
